document.docAuthor: Fontana, Tayara, Cóndor-Luján, Báslavi, Azevedo, Fernanda, Pérez, Thierry & Klautau, Michelle
document.docTitle: Ernstia adunca Fontana & Cóndor-Luján & Azevedo & Pérez & Klautau 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Diversity and distribution patterns of Calcareous sponges (subclass Calcinea) from Martinique

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Diversity and distribution patterns of Calcareous sponges (subclass Calcinea) from Martinique

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Ernstia with an apical actine strongly curved, forming a hook.
Etymology. From the Latin aduncus (= hooked, curved), for the shape of the apical actine of the tetractine.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Type Locality.
Le Rocher du Diamant , Martinique .

subSubSection.paragraph: Synonyms. Ernstia sp. nov. : Pérez et al. 2017: 13.

Type Material.
( Three specimens)
Holotype :
UFRJPOR 7644,
Le Rocher du Diamant
, Martinique ( 14°26.556' N – 61°2.408' W ), collected by F. Azevedo ,
25 April 2015
,
18.8 m
depth
.
Paratypes :
UFRJPOR 7422, Pointe Burgos , Anses d'Arlet , Martinique ( 14°29.787' N – 61°5.351' W ), collected by M. Klautau and T. Pérez , 0
6 December 2013
. UFRJPOR 7672, Le Rocher du Diamant , Martinique ( 14°26.556' N – 61°2.408' W ), collected by F. Azevedo ,
25 April 2015
,
18.8 m
depth.
Colour. Yellow alive and light beige in ethanol.

Description. Clathroid body formed by thin, irregular and loosely anastomosed tubes ( Figure 10A ). No cells with granules. Water-collecting tubes are present and they are very large and conspicuous ( Figures 10A–C ). Aquiferous system asconoid.
Skeleton. The skeleton has no special organisation ( Figure 10D ) and is formed by two categories of triactines and one of tetractines. Triactines and tetractines are present in the same proportion.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 10. Spicule measurements of
Ernstia adunca
sp. nov.
and
Ernstia chrysops
. H=holotype, P=paratype.

FIGURE 10.
Ernstia adunca
sp. nov. (UFRJPOR 7644). A. Specimen in situ (UFRJPOR 7422, picture previously published in Pérez et al. 2017). B. Specimen in ethanol. C. Water-collecting tube of the specimen UFRJPOR 7672. D. Tangential section. E. Triactine I. F. Triactines II. G. Tetractine. H. Apical actine (arrow) of a tetractine.

subSubSection.paragraph: Triactine I: Regular or subregular. Actines are cylindrical and straight or slightly undulated, with blunt tips ( Figure 10E ). Size: 27.5–65.0/2.5–5.0 µm.
Triactine II: Regular. Actines are conical to slightly conical with sharp or blunt tips ( Figure 10F ). Size: 81.1– 118.9/5.4–8.1µm.
Ecology. Specimens of this species were found protected from the sunlight.

Remarks. The only species of Ernstia with an apical actine strongly curved as in
E. adunca
sp. nov.
is E.

chrysops Van Soest & De Voogd, 2015
from Indonesia . The difference is that in
E. adunca
sp. nov.
the actine turns to the basal actines (360o), forming a hook ( Figures 10F–H ), while in
E. chrysops
it curves 90o. In addition, not all apical actines of
E. chrysops
are curved, while in
E. adunca
sp. nov.
, all of them are. Besides, the spicules of
E. chrysops
are larger than those of
E. adunca
sp. nov.
( Table 10 ). In our phylogenetic tree ( Figure 17 ),
E. adunca
sp. nov.
did not present intraspecific variation (boostrap 100% and p-distance of 0%), and was closer to
E. arabica
with bootstrap of 96% and p-distance ranging from 5.6% to 5.9%.
